review_title: An Overall Positive Place to Work
job_title: Gift Officer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: 1. Lots of ways to move up within the institution. Especially in University Advancement. 2. Stellar benefits, especially medical. I love that we can get specialist appointments within two weeks almost guaranteed. 3. Casual Fridays! Wear WashU gear and be happy you aren't in work clothes. 4. Good people. The people here are very sweet and down to earth. 5. WFH Two days a week. 6. A mission you can believe in.
cons: 1. Not a lot of room for creativity. As the staff grows, there is a need for more guidelines that prevent us from being creative without over planning for the possibilities. I think this has discouraged thinking outside the box. 2. Not a lot of opportunity to ask for raises more substantial than 2-3%. It's much easier to leave and come back to get that pay bump than it is to stick it out. Your only real chance for pay increase is promotion. 3. Tension between different teams and thinly veiled politics. This can be difficult and tiring to navigate. 4. An arm and a leg for parking. 5. Leadership clearly doesn't like the WFH policy and wants it gone. I think they keep it because people would be angry and leave if they got rid of it.

review_title: Well resourced institution, but very corporate
job_title: Associate Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Wash U has a large endowment, and if you can persuade the right people, you can get a good salary or support for projects and initiatives. The students are smart and engaged, and in general there's a lot of autonomy for faculty, though I'm sure that varies by department.
cons: Wash U has a very corporate environment, with layers upon layers of hierarchy, and it's not very centralized, so when you need to contact someone outside of your own department or division, it's often unclear who's responsible for a particular issue. When bringing visiting scholars to campus, I was bounced around between 4 or 5 different departments (HR, international payroll, etc.), and very few of the people I interacted with seemed to actually know or care about what they were doing. My experience is that if you keep your head down and focus on your own department or area, you can do great things here, but the more you have to interact with the vast administrative apparatus, the more difficult your life becomes.

job_title: Graduate Student in Saint Louis, MO
pros: As a grad student in the Psychology department, I had access to departmental conference travel ($600-800) each academic year. Other social science departments are similar. There were also internal awards for research projects and most faculty/PIs would have their own federal funding to offer additional support to students. My PI funded a week-long statistics training in another state. People are friendly and admin was always very helpful.
cons: If you adapt/assimilate to the individualistic culture of academia, WashU is a great place for a grad student. I talked to friends in other social science and humanities departments and the experience is fairly similar. For BIPOC students who have a hard time merely assimilating to new cultural norms because it feels inauthentic, there can be clashes with leadership who are performative in what DEI should look like. In my experience, there was a lot of cultural/black taxation--BIPOC students and faculty being over-burdened, compared to white counterparts, in community service roles around DEI.

review_title: If you want pay equity at Wash U, avoid MIR/Radiology
job_title: Research Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Can have a stable research staff job if you are in a well-funded field University-wide benefits are great
cons: I work in a research staff position that works closely with colleagues in identical jobs in Wash U Neurology and Psychiatry. It's an open secret among staff and among faculty in Radiology, Neurology, and Psychiatry who are writing grants that Mallinckrodt Institute of Radiology/MIR pays less than comparable staff positions in other departments. In many cases I've seen, a LOT less. I've talked with multiple junior faculty members who are making anywhere from $10-30k less than people at their same levels in Psychiatry and Neurology. These are high-performing new faculty members in Radiology, in many cases POC and/or women, who are collaborating closely with, performing identically to or better than, and in a lot of cases winning actual identical grants to their colleagues in Neurology and Psychiatry. These people are bringing in a TON of grant money for MIR and MIR refuses to pay them what other departments say they're worth. It's wild. In my own case and in the case of other staff colleagues at my level, research staff in Radiology are making $10-20k less than those with identical duties in Psychiatry and Neurology. In a few instances I've helped to train people in collaborator groups in roles just like mine who are making more than me as a baseline. It's frustrating. I'm aware of a Radiology colleague who was given a promotion and received new promotion-based duties 6 months before their salary was actually increased - and their request for back pay was denied. Trying to advocate for yourself or your team to MIR leadership sends you through a labyrinth of impossible challenges to justify exactly what the cause for change is ("pay equity with people who do the same thing I do" is not a good enough response for them) so ultimately nothing changes. Turnover at MIR is fairly constant for reasons like this, which means we are constantly training new people in our own department and spinning our wheels. MIR leadership is entirely uninterested in working for pay equity at any level and shuts it down right away if you broach the topic- they very much want to hide this information, but as I mentioned it's pretty common knowledge among staff and new faculty in various departments that they pay a lot less and are generally less flexible on things like promotions and remote work arrangements (MIR won't budge on this even if you are dealing with health issues or caregiving duties - I know someone great who is going to have to leave their MIR job over this, it's heartbreaking and I dearly hope they can transfer to Neurology). There's an upcoming window where they might make changes when a new chair of Radiology is chosen, but from my discussions with faculty the general feeling is that it's unlikely that any material changes will happen, and if so it would be incremental pay adjustments for faculty with no updates at the staff level. We'd all be very surprised if MIR goes for actual pay equity with other departments for either faculty or staff. If you are looking for a research staff job at Wash U and you have skills and experience to offer, try to avoid Radiology if you can. Turnover is fairly constant and they have repeatedly demonstrated aren't interested in making any changes, pay-based or otherwise, to encourage faculty/staff retention. If you are trying to get your foot in the door, it's fine, that's what a lot of us are doing here, just make sure you stay aware of your worth while you are here and leave when you have the experience to get a better deal.

review_title: Closer you are to receiving dependent college benefit, the closer you are to being forced out
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO

cons: Tenure Professors and Management have a free pass to be lazy, not teach/mentor, throw their weight around, and treat staff like dirt. Brown School is a prime example of this environment. TOXIC!!! Simply stated, if the person occupies an office, assume they will treat you like garbage and throw you under the bus at the drop of a dime. If you were lucky enough to be "grandfathered" in to the original Dependent College Benefit, beware. The closer you are to reaping the rewards of this benefit the closer you are to being pushed out the door. If the amount of benefit you are receiving is greater than your salary RUN!!!!! Parents if you are looking into a college for your children, please do your homework. Research professors who bring in revenues to the university use these funds to buy out of teaching. This means that all the professors used to promote this institution are not the ones that will be teaching your children. You are best to spend your hard earned money elsewhere.

job_title: IT Operations Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Great Benefits Package - 403b with employer match, Dental, Vision, Health, 4 weeks vacation per year, ample sick days.

Very diverse and intelligent coworkers - I am consistently impressed with the diversity and wide range of backgrounds of my colleagues. There are a *ton* of very bright people here. They will encourage you to expand your horizons.

Work/Life Balance - on the whole, the university leadership seems to recognize and stress the importance of maintaining a healthy balance. However, at levels below the upper administration that is often not the case.

Prestigious - Very well kept campus facilities, always highly ranked internationally. WashU is known as one of the best places to work in St. Louis.
cons:
WashU does not pay well in comparison to other large employers in the St. Louis area. If you are looking for a big salary $, this is not the place to go. They claim to be "competitive" with other employers because the benefits package is great. However, to take advantage of the majority of those benefits you will have to work here 10+ years and ultimately retire here. The huge problem that comes about from this type of setup (low salary, high benefits) is it causes the workforce to skew older and low performing. You have a huge amount of your workforce "coasting" until they reach retirement so they can ride off in the sunset with their huge benefits and retirement package. 

Conversely, younger IT folks with "cutting edge" skillsets are disinterested in working here because they don't want to commit 20+ years of their career to staying put in order to reap the benefits needed to make the overall compensation competitive.

job_title: Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The medical school is a very organized employer, and their response to COVID (safety procedures, transition to remote work, etc.) was phenomenal. I felt supported by the med school throughout the pandemic, even though there were temporary pay cuts. The retirement benefits are amazing.
cons:
On a research study, my experience was that the PIs were very distanced from the day-to-day of the study and from the study participants and research assistant. This sometimes led to communication disconnects. 
Also, I wish that the time-off (both vacation and sick leave) policy for new hires was more generous. This may have been for my department only, but it was very difficult to take any PTO before you had held your job for 6 months.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scholar in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Wash U School of Medicine is a vibrant academic community that consistently produces top-notch science.  The administration does a fine job of encouraging positive mentoring by its faculty, and has set up logical systems for supporting even postdoctoral researchers, a population that is often left neglected by administrations.
cons: For individuals comparing Wash U to coastal powerhouse research universities, the tendency is to look  at St. Louis as a hum-drum place.  St. Louis is a big small town, which comes with it both the good and bad things about each.  It is a good place to feel comfortable, but a relatively bad place to feel important.  If you can't stand the idea of feeling lost in the middle of the country, don't come here.  If you just want to be surrounded by outstanding science, and don't mind having a relatively quaint personal life, this is the best place I know.

job_title: Instructor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Washington University is a premier University in the midwest. It has very strong medical school and research program. The undergraduate program attracts top notch students from around the world. I enjoy working with a world class team of researchers on the medical school and feel that my research is important and well received by the larger academic community.  The health and retirement benefits provided are phenomenal.
cons: I am speaking only about my experience at the medical school. The medical school does not value PhD researchers as much as they should. There are limited avenues for advancement and there is generally weak support for career development. Being promoted to Assistant professor and above is a chore in many departments. Preferential treatment is given to those with MD's in terms of salaries, office space, opportunities for promotion, and recognition. Assistant Professor titles and office space are given out readily to MD's with no grant support and very limited research productivity. There are literally a dozen offices on my floor that are occupied one day a month. PhD's in my group often stall out at the Instructor level despite being highly productive and contributing to multiple center grants. I understand pay disparities as MD's can bring in income to the hospital, but PhD salaries are well below the value they bring to the University.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Unique experience, friendly work environment, little experience required, great benefits from Wash U. Overall, most new college graduates would be lucky to get this job.  Many people take the job simply to get 50% tuition assistance for a Washington University MBA.  After several years experience there is opportunity to move up, but it is likely more lucrative to use your experience at Wash U to transfer to the commercial/industrial side of clinical research, as academic institutions cannot pay very competitive salaries except to management.
cons: It is likely more lucrative to use your experience at Wash U to transfer to the commercial/industrial side of clinical research, as academic institutions cannot pay very competitive salaries except to management.  I did not personally know anyone who took this path though.  Also, to be blunt, this job is boring.  Your day is essentially shuffling papers and fixing paper work mistakes or creating new paper work mistakes that then have to be taken care of later. Some people are lucky enough to get to interact with patients, but that seems to lengthen their work hours quite a bit.

cons: Not a lot of opportunity for advancement. I don't feel as though my personal skills are being developed in my position, and I don't see my co-workers being challenged or moving up either. Everyone tends to get stuck in a rut and it takes hours and chains of emails to answer simple questions. There's a lot of procrastination and boredom because there's no momentum of leadership and growth.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Its a great opportunity to meet and interact with many other smart and interesting postdocs from all over the world.  Washington University has an outstanding Office of Postdoctoral Affairs (OPGA) whose purpose is to provide opportunities for postdocs to network with outside science professionals.  The OPGA also supports seminars where invited speakers discuss additional career options available to recent PhD grads and postdocs.  Additionally the OPGA funds and provides logistical support to the Wash U postdoc society, a committee of postdocs who meet regularly to organize events which support networking and career development.  Serving in the WUPS executive committee allows postdocs to demonstrate experience working on a team of scientists and learning important lessons about committee politics.
cons: Most faculty treat postdocs like cheap labor, having them work on projects that the faculty are interested in, rather than allowing postdocs to develop projects of their own.  The faculty seem to have forgotten that the postdoc experience is an opportunity for the postdoc to develop into a mature scientist.

job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
- Extremely flexible work schedule (can do part time during school year and full time during summers)
- Opportunities to present at conferences and gain valuable connections and insight into academia
- After sufficient time working in one lab (>1.5 years or so) you are essentially treated as a young graduate student by your professor
- If you stay in one lab for enough time you can get one or two publications prior to graduating (probably as second author but not impossible to be the first author depending on the lab)
- Does a great job of accelerating students into graduate school
cons:
- If you take this as a summer job, and you aren't really into research or the relevant field, you will be hideously bored.
- Expect your first half of a year to be grunt work more or less. There will be a lot of cleaning lab ware and doing literature searches. This gets better with time!
- Standard university pay in the Engineering department is $10/hr which over the summer is hard to sustain yourself off of if you are covering rent + food + etc.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I was a graduate student in the Division of Biology and Biomedical Sciences. I found the atmosphere to be very collaborative, and I can see that the graduate training program really prepared be well for a career in science (especially in comparison to the current institute that I am a post doc at now, and seeing how they run their graduate training program). I had many opportunities for presenting my research, attending relevant journal clubs, and attending lectures (within and across departments). I had all the resources I needed to move forward in my research, as well as great support from my lab, thesis committee, and department. I felt that there was a great sense of community, great scientific expertise, and the faculty really wanted to see the trainees succeed.
cons: I was in the PhD program for 7 years. In the end, I think the longer time spent helped me develop as a scientist.

review_title: Low Pay, Overworked Staff, and Forcing Employees to Mix Business and Personal Funds BUT the Benefits Sure are Great...
job_title: Professional Rater I in Saint Louis, MO
pros: decent benefits (inexpensive healthcare with good coverage, fairly generous sick time and 22 days earnable vacation per year)
cons: medical school labs receive little oversight so research staff are often overworked and denied overtime despite working 7+ day weeks; employees responsible for paying research subjects are expected to transfer cash out of their own personal bank accounts; compensation is egregiously low for research staff, even for people hired with bachelors and masters degrees

job_title: Registered Medical Assistant II in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great benefits, learning environment, inspiring patients,  intellectually stimulating.  Aesthetically, beautiful.  Metro link free passes. Amazing doctors to work with. Opportunity to learn if you initiate the interest.
cons: Poor management due to nepotism. After being hired and non-related,  8 people people I worked closely with were related by blood or by marriage from the Supervisor, Nurse staff, front desk, schedulers, and medical assistants.  $84.00 a month to park.  I lived nearer to work, (not walk able), than a link station. Staff appreciation, (in my department)   once a year but often not day to day.

job_title: Information Technology Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Inspiring mission, good benefits aside from salary, good work life balance, good atmosphere, potential for individual impact. This could be a "dream job". Could be, but isn't. So close in so many ways.
cons: Uninspiring leadership, no technical vision, lower than market salary, innability to grow or move around within the org, toxic culture between Danforth and Med School, lack of technical innovation.

job_title: Human Resources Consultant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The time off and other benefits were great, especially the education benefits that were in place at that time.
cons: Human Resources on the main campus was the worst department.  Unfortunately I found out after starting that the duration for a consultant was on average 1.5 years for the poor souls that worked on the main campus.  The environment was cold and interaction with others in the office was not allowed.  Work life balance was awful, and staff waited in fear for when it would be their turn to be targeted for bullying by the AVC and/or VC.  Turnover was high and the focus was on protecting the org from bad behaviors of Dean's and professors.  As in the medical field those that bring in the dollars were untouchable and the worker bee regular employees were expendable.

review_title: Upper echelons know what they're doing, but academics are not always the best at managing their departments.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Many professors are good to work for and undergraduates are often bright and interested students.
Good research environment, especially at the Medical School.

Good planning to accommodate cross-disciplinary research and emerging fields of science.

A lot of capital investment as of late, especially in scientific research labs.

Free mass-transit passes for students, staff and faculty, reasonable benefits for graduate researchers.

Located in a very family-friendly city with the campus in close proximity to a number of free cultural / recreational opportunities such as the Zoo, Art Museum, History Museum and Science Center.

Many collaborations and tie-ins with other local universities and local industry.

Paid subscription / access to a a large number of scientific journals.
cons: Professors in groups can often be short-sighted and slow to act, especially in certain departments.

review_title: Great place, but hard work is expected and not rewarded
job_title: in Saint Louis, MO
pros: It's a great institution.  The students, faculty, and staff are all high achieving and motivated individuals.  There is a strong culture of support and an ability for anyone to take an idea and run with it.  As a private institution, job security is much higher than at other colleges and universities.  the benefits packages are good too.
cons: Hard work is rarely rewarded.  There is little to no upward mobility in terms of establishing a long term career here.  People at the highest levels stay here forever which slows innovation and change to a snail's pace.  Pay isn't bad, but don't expect any big raises or significant changes to where you start.

review_title: The rumors are true, it is the best place to work in St. Louis!
job_title: Accounting Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for Washington University are the opportunities for advancing your career both academicaly and professionally.  Vacation time is extremely generous and the health benefits are above and beyond more affordable than other companies in the area.  The tuition benefits are second to none in St. Louis and are the most generous of any I'v heard of.  In addition, the faculty and staff are some of the most accomplished in their fields, creating one of the best places to work in St. Louis.
cons: The only downside to working at Washington University is that it's too good to leave.  Even if I could make more money working elsewhere, the tuition, health and vacation benefits far outweigh those I could outside the University.  Also, the location is ideal for my commute, which is a total of 4 miles round trip.

job_title: Investments Intern in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Excellent position to learn at the feet of talented fund managers. Very bright, collegial, intellectually curious staff; overall a great group who are willing to teach you the ins and outs of evaluating investment opportunities and balancing all the issues a FoF faces. You'll spend time at the wipe board with directors, talking about performance metrics, as well as sitting at the table opposite VC and HF managers.
cons: Assignment workflow to you will be uneven since it's based on manager needs; starting off everything will be grunt work as the managers decide what they can send your way.

review_title: Not what we used to be
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Berlin
pros: There are some really sharp and passionate staff at WU. People that care and walk the talk.
cons:
Glacial speed of progress and bloated capital project budgets are impacting the pace of necessary and modern change (i.e. implementation of VDI and accessibility platforms)
Inbred decision making (only an elite few opinions seem to matter)
Jumping on the D/I bandwagon and way too focused on checking boxes as opposed to doing meaningful and impactful work.
Folks are getting jaded by the lack of progress 
Not as student-focused as it once was, largely due to a shift in Student Services (now known as Student Affairs). The days of every student by name and story are clearly over.

review_title: Good reputation, but unless you are a doctor, don't expect much.
job_title: Professional Rater II in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The medical campus provides good benefits with regard to vacation and sick leave time.  The name recognition will also gain attention.
cons: Low pay relative to education and experience and very small raises some years with salary freezes other years. It is difficult to near impossible to move into a higher level position with zero assistance from HR. There were always safety issues at the WUSM campus with frequent car break-ins and other crime.  Each group within each department is different and there is not much of a sense of cohesion among the University due to this.  Added high cost of parking only exacerbates the low pay, nearly $100/month when I left.  For a premier medical institution, the health care benefits could be better for staff.

job_title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I have solidified my mastery of the course material and been able to help dozens of students.  I have a good relationship with my professor who is always available and helpful.
cons: Grading can be time consuming and unrewarding and students often wait until the day before something is due to complete it, leading to office hours that are occasionally packed with long wait times for the students and never-ending work for the TAs (though this might be considered sort of good, depending on how rewarding you find helping others to be)

review_title: Excellent research environment at a top university
job_title: Research Administrator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: School of Medicine at Washington University in Saint Louis offers flexibility, good work-life balance and great benefits.I am passionate about innovative research and advancement of human health, WashU is a great place to be if these causes are close to your heart. Incredibly bright and talented faculty and dedicated staff.
cons:
Extremely decentralized organization, lots of process improvement solutions needed to eliminate redundancy and inefficiencies. 
Salaries do not follow the going market rate. People often stay for the benefits and job security. Many of those who want to truly excel professionally and expect a level of remuneration appropriate with their experience and education are forced to leave.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good stipend in certain departments, university healthcare is decent though doesn't include optical. Beautiful campus, interesting research.
cons: WashU is very undergrad-centric; they will do anything to make the undergraduates happy even at the expense of staff/grad students/faculty. Some departments do not have livable stipends for grad students and the university has gone to great legal pains to try to keep it that way. Affordable dental/optical/childcare options are not available to grad students (maybe they are for faculty/staff). Hospital visits are required to be Barnes-Jewish unless you are 50 miles from campus. So if you live off campus and have an emergency, the health insurance will not pay unless you drive yourself or beg the ambulance to bring you to B-J. No support for how to file taxes when you're getting fellowship/stipend.

review_title: To be the best, you have to work harder than the rest.
job_title: Research Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Outstanding reputation and unmatched research programs. This place will boost your resume and provide you with the experience you need to build your career.
cons:
LONG hours. They will make you an "exempt" (salaried) employee so they don't have to pay you when you work 80+ hour work weeks regularly. 

The culture is toxic and employees are so siloed but competitive they will do whatever it takes to make you look bad (instead of looking good together as a team). 

Pay is nowhere near fair market price. They have "salaried professionals" making less than $30k a year and SENIOR coordinators make $40k to LOW $50s. Not the place to go if you want to make money (as a staff member).

job_title: Facility Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The benefits are outstanding. The University is a leader in the industry and being a part of that is extremely rewarding. Pay scales are comparable to other businesses for lower and middle level positions.
cons: The Medical School is experiencing a great deal of upper level leadership changes and turnover and the direction it seems to be going is more business driven and has created a highly stressful working environment for all levels of employment. What was once considered a place who valued all of their employees and their input by their employees is becoming a company whose employees are always wondering who's job will be gone next.

review_title: I have no idea what to put here.
job_title: Librarian in Saint Louis, MO
pros: After 7 years' employment, your child/ren get free tuition at Wash U, or half of their tuition paid at any other university. That is the major benefit of working here. The sick leave and vacation are standard. The health plan is United Healthcare, which has a reasonable monthly cost but sub-par copays and coverage. Maybe that should be a con.
cons: Sometimes it seems as though we should all be paid more--this is a highly respected  academic institution with a huge endowment. Salaries are competitive for this area, but not on a nationwide scale.

job_title: Public Health Research Technician in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great organization for undergraduate or graduate students looking for part-time research experience. The labs are very understanding of your academic schedule and are flexible with your work schedule. The Institute of Public Health has various divisions and labs that have diverse research objectives. The Institute works closely with WUSTL and other health-oriented organizations, which may provide students and employees with networking opportunities. Many of the labs work closely together which can be helpful if looking to participate in other projects or increase your hours. The staff are generally friendly and well-educated.
cons: Graduate students are at the "bottom of the food chain" are subject to budget cuts or grant cycle terminations. One of the projects I worked on suddenly cut my hours in half leading me to scramble for a new project to supplement my hours. The pay is really, really poor especially for such a well-endowed university.

review_title: Offers great work/life balance and benefits with a relaxed schedule.
job_title: Project Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Washington University offers one of the best benefits packages in the St. Louis area. I also enjoy the generous vacation time and the ability to take days off whenever I like. The weekly hours are also consistent and there isn't much need to work over time. Saint louis offers a very low cost of living, so having time off can actually be enjoyed with smaller paychecks.
cons: There are few chances for advancement or promotions and there's limited exposure to new ideas since the university departments tend to be insulated. Although Washington University is a huge organization, it is really just a lot of smaller departments with varying amounts of resources.

review_title: Pretty good. Not out of line of how post-docs at other institutions are treated
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Nice people to work with in general. Not the competitive craziness that you can see in other top institutions. Although a lot of that varries from lab to lab. There are definitely people who work 80 hours a week, but there are also others who work 50.
cons: The post-doc benefits are okay, but definitely have limitations, especially if you get your own grant money. In this case you are considered a non-employee and lose several benefits. One of the most significant is how they figure out your medical insurance. I'd definitely ask HR/ Post-doc society about that if money is a concern.

job_title: Post Doctoral Research Associate in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Access to and mentoring from faculty with high and consistent levels of federal funding.
Extensive academic resources for research and grant writing
Support staff are professional and willing to work through issues that arise 
Excellent facilities
Superior Career Center staff for post-docs
Excellent health benefits
cons:
Inconsistent approaches to mentoring -  not all post docs get the same level of mentoring or faculty investment
Faculty not able to assist pragmatically with job search
Poor and inconsistent links to valuable university resources 
Very low pay
Expectation is that you will put career first, family and personal life on hold for duration of post doc.

review_title: Washington University School of Medicine holds many fantastic opportunities for high-level collaborative research.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scholar in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Friendly and collaborative environment with world-class leaders in biomedical research. Interdisciplinary interactions are stressed. Tremendous opportunities for translational research bridging basic science at the benchtop with applications within a clinical setting.
cons: It is academia, so the pay could be better. At times, the work-life balance can tilt a bit too far towards work, But, this is balanced by travel to international conferences to speak with and present work to world thought leaders, as well as the time-flexibility inherent in academia.

job_title: Applications Systems Analyst/Programmer-associate in Saint Louis, MO
pros: You'll get exposure to some of the latest Business Intelligence technology, in a highly structured Dev Ops team. The pay and benefits are well above market average. As colleges go, you're never at risk of "the company" going belly up, so job security is plus. There's virtually no stress involved in working at Wash U, and your evenings and weekends are virtually guaranteed to be yours.
cons: Everything moves VERY slowly. You may end up waiting approvals to do the job you were hired for months after your actual start date. You'll also be expected to support sunset technologies from the 1990s, which won't be mentioned in the interview process. There's little to no room for growth as most of the staff is waiting for their kids to get to (or through) college.

review_title: Reputation well deserved for academic excellence but difficult to advance
job_title: Instructor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Academically very strong with excellent research and researcher:   Washington University has a strong academic reputation that is well deserved.  It is able to attract the best students, post-docs, fellows, and faculty.  The research done is at a top level.  The school's reputation also helps in getting grants.
cons: Very difficult and time consuming to advance to next level:  It is somewhat competitive, but not as competitive as other well known schools.  However, it is difficult to be promoted.  The argument is that Washington University has a high standard and this justifies the longer time to reach the next level.  However, this policy is not applied uniformly to everyone.  Some are favored while others are not.

review_title: State of the Art People and Technology, but Low Pay and Stiff Competition
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Saint Louis, MO
pros: WashU Med is a leader in the field of research and as a recipient of grant funding...not to mention you have access to state of the art technology and are surrounded by highly educated and qualified people.
cons: The pay is low and the competition is stiff.  There is not much of an insentive for promotions or pa raises since they can replace you with another highly qualified person at the drop of a hat.

review_title: The overall quality & intellectual integrity of the faculty & staff is very good; rewards for good work were meager.
job_title: Research Scientist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: My employment in the academic environment was marked by inter-lab cooperation, helpfulness & sharing of resources.  The work hours were flexible & the vacation allowance was quite generous.
cons: My employment at The Genome Institute was unrewarding.  Lack of cooperation among groups & adherence to rigid hierarchical relationships wasted a lot of time.  Problems that could have been easily solved with inter-group communication & cooperation at lower levels were prolonged by hierarchical communication & "decision by committee".

job_title: Information Systems in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Benefits include 22 days vacation, 12 days sick, 8 holidays, great healthcare benefits, great employees, tuition reimbursement for you, your spouse, and children, 7% 403b match, which bumps higher when you hit 10 years, etc
cons: Management is something to be desired. Lack of communication, lies, no concern for yearly reviews, favoritism, no reasoning of raises, no pay for performance, you won't be able to tell how the departments have made it so long on such poor operations from the top. HR is another sore to be weary of, with any concerns being voiced back to management with your name attached only to cause disdain from peers and management.

review_title: It really depends on who you work for!
job_title: Program Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great Benefits, beautiful campus, generally nice colleagues
cons: It really depends on who you work under. I know colleagues who work under awful Researchers and administrators but then move departments and end up loving it. Their family leave policy is something to be desired considering all the other work life balance/ family benefits they offer

job_title: Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I worked in a research team within the Dept of Urologic Surgery's clinical research team and the staff and supervisors were amazing. I was one of a handful of students, but if you show you're halfway competent and have people skills they were so eager to invest in young people. The more I was there, the more ownership they gave me over projects.
cons:
Some Urology physicians were sweet and kind, other were terrible to work with and RAGING sexists. I tried to limit contact with them as much as possible.
Revolving door of student researchers was frustrating - as much as staff tried to ensure good results students would be on projects for months and still mess things up -  and I had to clean after their messes

review_title: Great benefits, not so great salary.
job_title: Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great health insurance, dental insurance, vision coverage, etc. They will match up to 7% in 403b contributions after two years employment. Full tuition at Wash U for dependents or half of Wash U's tuition towards another school after a certain number of years.  22 paid vacation days a year.
cons: Trying to use FMLA leave was kind of a hassle. Salary leaves much to be desired. Didn't see any prospects for advancing my career. There are tuition benefits for the employee, but they are limited to using the University college, whose classes are rather limited.

job_title: PhD Student in Saint Louis, MO
pros: the medical research is very high quality, the people are great (post-docs, grad-students, PIs), cost of living is low, there are great resources for research, good collaborative environment, departmental offices have friendly and helpful staff
cons: The benefits.  They provide very poor health insurance for graduate students whose departments are housed on main campus (it's different for the medical campus).  Dental is very expensive, no vision coverage is offered.  The quality of the student health care services is very low, targeted towards the needs of undergraduate students, and difficult to get to.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great supportive environment for postdocs, notably led by the DBBS-sponsored postdoctoral society. Many opportunities for professional development available through the career center as well as through separate activities administered by the postdoc society and DBBS. Presence of student-led entrepreneurial groups (BALSA, IDEALabs, BEC) leaves options open for students interested in careers outside of academia.
cons: Below average pay compared to colleagues industry. Obtaining a tenure-track faculty position is the golden stamp that will get you noticed by colleagues. Prepare to slip by under the radar as a postdoc.

review_title: if you have kids about to go to college great. otherwise, work somewhere else
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
22 days vacation
dependent tuition assistance
free metrolink pass
cons:
tuition assistance for employees is for show - degree options are limited to UCollege (and there's only a few mostly useless options to pick from, like Anthropology. Not allowed to enroll in any of the 'real' programs as WU if you're a day employee.
expensive parking even though they own the lots
pay is lower than industry
health insurance is high compared to other companies in the area

review_title: Department chair does not care about "secretaries" - we have no opinion
job_title: Secretary III in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The physician I work for is AWESOME. He shows his appreciation to everyone on his team, therefore, has the best team in our department. Vacation days, retirement is OUTSTANDING!
cons: 1.5% raise with increased out of pocket benefit premiums/copays and cost of living. Some staff end up with a decrease in salary. Does NOT promote  higher education for staff. SECRETARY is an archaic term and is demeaning. No one in this University is a secretary!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: You have access to the best resources and smart people to learn from.
cons: Pay is not competitive. They often hire the person who can be paid lower even though you are qualified for the job and would be the better fit. Grant funding is decreasing, research jobs are paying less or eliminated. Non-qualified people conducting sloppy research because it's cheaper to combine jobs then to pay the right person to do the job correctly. More likely to make lateral move than upward. Strange attitude about increasing someone's pay.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Dallas, TX
pros: Working at WashU while completing my Masters was a great experience with flexibility of hours. The faculty give you an opportunity to learn from the position and understand that it is not a position for medial work.
cons: Parking of campus is always difficult, but honestly working with a faculty member I respect at a University with students with a lot of potential was a great experience.

review_title: It could be better, but it can also be worse!
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The best reason to work for Washington University is the academic freedom to work on research projects of my own interests. Some of the brightest students attend Washington University, which allows for research to progress at a fast pace.
cons:
There is a strong hierarchy on campus. Most department chairs have been in a leadership role for 20 years. I think that they are too far removed from younger faculty, staff, and students to lead successfully. The facilities are quite poor and construction is slow.

The total compensation package (salary and benefits) is poor. Health care coverage needs to be improved.

job_title: in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Very collaborative environment. Not a lot of pressure to produce results, as long as there is learning involved in the process. Ample opportunities to work on and display scientific and presentation skills. Very conducive to international students. St. Louis is a nice city to live in, very affordable and lots of things to do.
cons: Career fairs need to be organized, especially for the medical school, for students wanting to join industry after graduating. More tie-ups with industry so that there are more internship opportunities with them

job_title: Student Researcher in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Lab PI's are generally very accessible. Many faculty have multiple grants and have good funding. Labs are all well stocked. Great opportunity to learn from and work with the best and brightest in their fields. Generally, you determine the hours you work.
cons: Student researchers are generally stuck with the grunt work. Sometimes it can become very dull and your work is rarely seen in the end product such as a published article. Pay is usually or slightly better than minimum wage.

review_title: Great place with friendly people and great benefits
job_title: Resident Adviser in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The pros of working at WashU begin with the people.  Much of the professional staff and faculty are very kind and caring.  Most people have high regard for the university and try their best to better it.  It is an incredibly supportive work environment.
cons: The University community is very separated from the larger St. Louis community.  Every once in a while there is an initiative to try to bridge that divide, but nothing has been too successful on a large scale.  There is not much diversity within the socioeconomic status of students. Also, depending upon your department, there is not a very healthy live-work balance.

job_title: Researcher in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Benefits good, but if you are a minority you will never get to upper level positions. If you by chance to get to an upper level position, you have to fight to stay there and prove yourself 10 times more than your counterpart. The culture is set up to keep people at the bottom, especially minorities meaning black people.
cons: The culture hear is very cut throat. Employees and Supervisors allow anything to go even the work environment becomes hostile. No one does anything about the issues at hand, but rather join in on the harassment that is taken place.  All levels of management just overlook what is going on or participating.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Not treated like a second-class citizen like some institutions.  Ample opportunities to be involved in high-impact inter-disciplinary research.  As far as the employee side of the graduate experience goes, all in all a good experience.  Best part is being surrounded by incredibly talented and motivated people day in, day out.
cons: Well, you don't get paid much compared to a full time industry or academic job but you are technically a student.  A student creating ridiculous amounts of IP and novel contributions in your field but that's the system.  Health insurance was anemic, student health was generally sub-par for anything more than what you see in undergraduates.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scholar in Saint Louis, MO
pros: My co-workers are open minded and very easy to work with. Our research was exciting and interesting and the perks were great. The skywalk means you can avoid uncomfortable weather and the transit passes save lots of money.
cons: Biomedical research is demanding so you have to be willing to work hard to succeed. There are plenty of research resources and others are always willing to help, even if you are in different labs. Jobs after academia are difficult to find since employers have false assumptions about academics.

job_title: Access Control Host in Saint Louis, MO
pros: All of the customers and co-workers are very kind and fun to talk to. You choose your hours, and there is a lot of flexibility at a place open from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m. on weekdays.
cons: Sometimes it can be boring during slow shifts.

review_title: Excellent private company to work for. Very involved in community. Great benefits package. Competitive salary
job_title: Police Officer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The best benefits package offered anywhere. They really care about their employees and listen to them. They go out of their way to find new and creative ways to help their employees from free metro passes to a diverse benefits plan.
cons: Because it is mandatory to submit something in this section, the price of parking. But they offer you to have it taken out of your paycheck so it doesn't have to be paid at once. And again, they offer free metro passes so you can park somewhere else for free and utilize this service

job_title: Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Wshington University has great benefits. Employess make takes classes for free(up to 7 hours per semester for undergraduates), three weeks vacation, 10 days of sick leave per year and tution benefits for children of employees.
cons: The pay could be better. The university compensation is based on your title so the more fancier the title the better pay for basically doing the same job as someone without the title. It's  an decent place to work and the benefits can't be beat but there is a well defined hiearchy within the school.

review_title: Misguided, poor management, certain people will turn on you to protect themselves
job_title: in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good benefits, a few good and knowledgeable people. The environment is generally nice to work in. Lots of different learning experiences.
cons: Management is constantly changing point of view. Many projects are started and then never finished. Certain staff and faculty are only interested in bettering themselves.It felt like no matter what you did someone would not like it. Everything is so disjointed, it never feels like your part of something bigger.

review_title: Medical School campus - A job that led to nowhere
job_title: Secretary/Assistant in Saint Louis, MO

Nationally recognized quality institution.
The Medical School staff includes great physicians and research.
University benefits such as health care and vacation time.
cons:
Culture - people looking out for themselves - no teamwork. The longest tenured employees do the least amount of work and create a hostile environment .
No opportunities for promotion or advancement.
Relatively low pay scale for the average employee which is not balanced because of costs for health care and parking.

job_title: Professional Rater II in Saint Louis, MO

They always have extra employee perks that I was able to add in later... like workout facilities, free conferences, days off to explore happenings around campus... My supervisor was fantastic.
cons: In order to receive the daytime educational benefits, you have to work at night, and day employees have pretty limiting options for night classes that can really advance your career. I would have liked my schedule to have been a bit more flexible, so I could have gotten an extra bachelor's degree... or have started my MBA.

review_title: Nice to be around greatness, but to get a raise or promotion, you have to get another offer
job_title: Senior Associate Director in Saint Louis, MO
pros: There is outstanding research performed here and it's great to be able to support that.  The best and brightest in St. Louis have some connection to this university.  The Danforth family is very respectable and others have followed their example and made great investments here that have impact all over the world.  There are high standards here that make it a welcome challenge for someone willing to strive for the best.  There are several smart, good managers in A&D.
cons: A 2% annual raise is about all you can expect.  In spite of hard work and ace performance reviews, very few people seem to understand how to get promoted.  Young men get "great opportunities" even though the department is full of capable women.  There are obvious favorites and people in the "in crowd."  Those who keep their nose to the grindstone and try to get recognized just for doing a good job find themselves passed over to make room for the squeaky wheels.  Some managers are absolutely horrible and no one seems to do anything about it. Those realities can be disheartening.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO

cons: No downsides not found at other universities; having your life dictated by your advisor and thesis committee.  Also, there aren't a lot of other universities in the immediate area of the same caliber, so it limits collaboration across campuses.

job_title: in Saint Louis, MO

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Saint Louis, MO

Very flexible schedules.

review_title: I absolutely loved working for Washington University.  The experience will vary by position and departmen.

-Medical, Vision, Long Term Disability

job_title: PhD Student in Saint Louis, MO

review_title: Genome Institute: good work, exploitative management

review_title: I have been a grad student in biomedical engineering, working in the Orthopaedic Surgery department at the medical schoo

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO

review_title: Great place for research, great community

review_title: A great place to be both a graduate student and employee.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Saint Louis, MO

job_title: Financial Analyst in Saint Louis, MO

cons: Con is although the benefits are very good at WU, the salaries of accountants/ analysts and beyond in financial positions are CONSIDERABLY less than working in corporate positions.

review_title: Computer Science Department was incredibly friendly

review_title: If the pay could keep up, this place would be perfect
job_title: Project Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great benefits, beautiful campus, and depending on your position, supervisor, and department, you can have a lot of flexibility with your schedule. This makes trying to find work/life balance actually feasible.

After a few years, the people who are coming in are hired in at a higher salary than your raises have added up to. After several years, it feels like you are making less money than you did when you started.

job_title: Tech Analyst II in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great Benefits at affordable costs. Working for the medical school you feel you have job security.
cons: It can be a difficult place to get your foot in the door. Depending on the field you are in, department & management, sometimes it can be hard to get promotions. Typically raises average only 2-3% annually.

review_title: Good environment for PhD students relative to competition
job_title: PhD Candidate in Saint Louis, MO
pros: WashU does a great job providing an exceptional environment for PhD students. They consistently pay a higher cost of living adjusted salary than just about every other university and put a lot of effort into making a great experience for PhD students. My experience is in the DBBS program
cons:
WashU does a great job of keeping up with, or staying ahead of, the Jones', so to speak. However the whole academic system for PhD students just feels dirty. It feels a lot like a pyramid scheme. PhD students are severely underpaid for their skill level because of the 'education' and degree that they receive, but in most other ways are treated like an employee. What makes it feel dirty is that, the position that PhD's are trained for (Professorships in Academia) are only obtained by roughly 15% of the graduates. While PhD typically are able to transfer their skills to another area this problem is often downplayed, but that doesn't  change the fact that transitions away from Academia are not easy to pull off and there is not sufficient 'training' and support from the university to help students in this process. So the University gets a severe discount in labor costs because of this system and on the back end says to the students "Thanks for all the hard work suckers! Good luck figuring out on your own how to make a living off of the skills we taught you." 

Granted this problem is not limited only to WashU but all of Academia, so to be fair, relative to other universities WashU does extraordinarily well.

review_title: University taking advantage of PhD student labor
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The good parts of being a graduate teaching assistant (as a PhD student) at Wash U included working with the undergraduate students and having (some) time to do my own research and writing. Some of the faculty were also lovely and provided excellent mentorship and support (but not all of the faculty fall into this category).
cons: There were a number of bad parts to working as a graduate teaching assistant at Wash U. First, the university took advantage of doctoral student labor by requiring us to be teaching assistants but without properly paying us or providing good enough benefits commensurate to the labor we were performing. By exploiting graduate students this way, the university could avoid hiring more tenure-track faculty with full benefits, undermining a stable and fully-compensated labor force at many levels of the university. Second, completing the research and writing necessary to obtain my PhD while being a teaching assistant was often difficult - teaching took up so much of my time that I often felt I did not have adequate time remaining to actually do or write up my research.

review_title: Good place to develop academic research skills
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Saint Louis, MO
pros: A lot of research infrastructure around, core facilities available to provide services at a discounted price. Possibilities for collaborations within the university.
cons: Job opportunities if moving on to non-academic track. Local pharma / large biotech companies are not hiring / cutting employees. Smaller biotech companies exist but the training may not be as good.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I had my own desk and computer which was nice for a part time job
cons:
The student body is full of stuck up kids
The people who work there all think they are a little bit better than you
I am a responsible person and they didn't trust me to do anything, they immediately distrusted me before giving me a chance to prove myself one way or the other.  This experience was similar to other people in my position as well.

job_title: Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good Benefits, Intelligent co-workers, interesting job. If you are satisfied with status-quo this is the place for you.  Parking is available. Cafeterias are close to some offices.
cons: Terrible salary, not a lot of room for advancement. A lot of micro-managers with no real managerial skills, unfortunately.  Many researchers and those in supervisory roles do not have a lot of social skills so effective management is not easily found.

job_title: Scientist in Lake St Louis, MO
pros: You have opportunity to access and work on latest technology. Your name might appear in some top journals but far behind. Slightly better than similar jobs in the university.
cons: Your hard work may not be given any credit. Most of them now tend to be given to managers. Promotion can be so hard to get even you really deserve it.

job_title: Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Flexible hours, various opportunities. You're working at a top-tier university and conducting world-class research. There's a lot of cross-collaboration between schools (for example, between the med school and Danforth campus) that gives you the chance to try new things.
cons: Your experience will likely depend on your PI. Some PI's are very nice, flexible, understanding, and supportive. Others are not so much. Definitely research the PI and ask around before you take a job with them. The engineering school tends to pay students on an hourly basis and very poorly--even if it's not a work/study position.

review_title: Prepare to be overlooked and backstabbed
job_title: Research Scientist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great benefits, but they are constantly cutting them. Decent co-workers

They will steal credit for your work, lie about authorship and will roll over for any faculty. Always. The HR is a nightmare. Some of the worst people I have ever met. 

In the lab I was in I consistently worked 60 hours a week, but was told that I needed to take a full sick day for taking an hour to see a physician in the morning.

review_title: Research Technician II at WashU Med School Review

job_title: Information Technology in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I found no pros while working for this employer.
cons: Low salaries, dishonest management and leadership, no work-life balance, above all poor morals are supported and rewarded at this university.  I was appalled and disgusted by the behavior of many members of management during my time here.  I was regularly scheduled to work 60+ hours each week with no comp time; Management can and will take advantage of you at every opportunity.  The department was short staffed but new hires were not coming through the door as a result of a long and burdensome process with HR to list new openings so we had to give up our personal lives to keep the department afloat.  My salary was the lowest I have ever earned in my field which I initially had accepted, as I had heard great things about this university-- which I found to be untrue.  I found other employment and moved on peacefully after a year of little sleep and no personal life.  Years later I discovered from my current job (completely across the country) that the manager at Washington University St. Louis had placed many horrible lies on my HR record upon my departure such as "Employee cursed out the manager" and "Employee was terminated".  Working their employees to death pushed us out the door, then to top it off they took out their frustrations of being short staffed due to their poor management on the former employees who did nothing but work day and night 7 days a week to keep a department running.  I am exhausted just thinking about sitting at work for a solid 3 full days with no sleep during an upgrade and I was told that I could not leave, by management who went home for 18+ hours each day during this upgrade.  I DO NOT recommend working for Washington University St. Louis in ANY capacity.  They have illegally and unethically tarnished my employment record after a committed peaceful employment with them.  Management is childish to say the least and I am sorry I ever worked there.  Worst job of my life.
